thread.title: Enda Kenny's refusal to name an election date is distracting from real political issues, says Gerry Adams
thread.title_full: Enda Kenny's refusal to name an election date is distracting from real political issues, says Gerry Adams

author: Pat Flanagan
title: Enda Kenny's refusal to name an election date is distracting from real political issues, says Gerry Adams
text:
Enda Kenny's refusal to name an election date is distracting from real political issues, says Gerry Adams 19:21, 9 Oct 2015 The Taoiseach is under increasing pressure to name the date of the general election as speculation mounts it will be called for November Share   Gerry Adams and Enda Kenny 
The Taoiseach’s refusal to name an election date is distracting from real political issues, it was claimed today. 
Enda Kenny is under increasing pressure to name the date of the general election as speculation mounts it will be called for November after the Budget. 
Labour TDs and ministers are furious with Enda Kenny for refusing to repeat earlier promises that the country will not go to the polls until the spring. 
Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams today claimed that the Government’s failure to do so is a distraction from the real issues. 
He said: “The intense media speculation around a date for the election is a distraction from the real issues that are bearing down on citizens at this time. 
“However, the Taoiseach’s refusal to deal with the issue and the obvious discomfiture of his Tánaiste Joan Burton does expose this Government as a coalition of chaos. REUTERS/Cathal McNaughton Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams 
“The fact is that Mr Kenny is focused on getting enough seats to ensure his re-election as Taoiseach.” 
Deputy Adams also hit out at the Taoiseach over the Coalition’s record on dealing with the health and homelessness crisis. 
He added: “Michael McGrath (Fianna Fail finance spokesman) was right when he said that the Government had adopted Fianna Fáil policy on the economy. 
“What he failed to say was they obviously adopted Fianna Fáil policy on Health and have sustained the chaos in our health services as well as in housing, emigration and education.” 
It is known that a rift has opened up in the Coalition over the Taoiseach’s failure to give a commitment that the Government will run its full term. 
Labour leader Joan Burton said she wants to time to allow the Banking Inquiry to report its findings and for important legislation to be enacted. Stephen Collins/Collins Photos Joan Burton TD 
The Tanaiste also believes that a spring election would allow the public more time to see an improvement in their living standards thanks to next week’s Budget. 
She said that her objective was to see a lowering of the Universal Social Charge, especially for low and middle-income earners. 
Meanwhile the Anti-Austerity Alliance has proposed a 10% increase in the effective income tax rate on the top 10% of income earners to raise €2.7billion. 
The party is also calling for an emergency 2% millionaire’s tax and for the abolition of the USC for those earning less than €35,000. 
In its budget document it proposes to half the USC for those earning between €35,000 and €70,000.
